question: Will the Great Lakes ice coverage be between 15.0% and 30.0% (inclusive) on March 30, 2025?
reasoning:
Based on the information gathered, here are some key facts:

1. As of March 15, 2025, the Great Lakes Consolidated Ice Coverage is 15.63%. This is within the target range of 15.0% to 30.0% for the resolution of the question.
2. Individual ice coverage for the lakes as of March 15, 2025, are:
   - Lake Superior: 11.54%
   - Lake Michigan: 11.83%
   - Lake Huron: 21.79%
   - Lake Erie: 28.00%
   - Lake Ontario: 11.94%

The current ice coverage is just above the lower threshold of 15.0%. Given that the present date is March 23, 2025, and the ice coverage is already within the desired range, it is likely that the ice coverage will remain within this range until March 30, 2025, unless there are significant weather changes.

Considering historical trends and current conditions, the probability that the Great Lakes ice coverage will be between 15.0% and 30.0% on March 30, 2025, is relatively high.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.75

search_results.title: https://medium.com/michigan-news/daily-great-lakes-ice-cover-report-march-15-2025-c658096ce57d
search_results.content:
---
title: Daily Great Lakes Ice Cover Report — March 15, 2025
author: Thumbwind Publications
url: https://medium.com/michigan-news/daily-great-lakes-ice-cover-report-march-15-2025-c658096ce57d
hostname: medium.com
sitename: Michigan News
date: 2025-03-15
---
# Daily Great Lakes Ice Cover Report — March 15, 2025

Winter is now waning across the upper Great Lakes region. As ice cover is reduced, changes in weather patterns and lake activities will be seen. This daily Great Lakes ice cover report provides the latest updates on ice conditions across the lakes.

**Lake Superior:** 11.54%

**Lake Michigan:** 11.83%

**Lake Huron:** 21.79%

**Lake Erie:** 28.00%

**Lake Ontario:** 11.94%

**Lake St. Clair:** 14.50%

**Great Lakes Consolidated Ice Coverage:** 15.63%

Data from GLERL.NOAA.GOV. Stay tuned for daily updates on Great Lakes ice cover as we monitor changing conditions throughout the season.

search_results.title: https://glisa.umich.edu/resources-tools/climate-impacts/great-lakes-ice-coverage/
search_results.content:
---
title: Great Lakes Ice Coverage
url: https://glisa.umich.edu/resources-tools/climate-impacts/great-lakes-ice-coverage/
hostname: umich.edu
sitename: glisa.umich.edu
date: 2017-08-01
---
# Great Lakes Ice Coverage

**NOTE: This page is no longer updated as of 2021, and more recently updated information is now available through GLISA’s Sustained Assessment of the Great Lakes and Great Lakes Retrospectives and Prospectives pages.**

**Summary**

- The number of days per winter with lake ice coverage has declined since the start of record in 1973.
1 - In most areas, ice cover declines were a sudden shift as opposed to a gradual decline. For Lakes Michigan, Erie, and Ontario the shift occurred in the mid-1980s, but for Lakes Superior and Huron the shift occurred during the 1997/98 winter.
23 - Ice cover has decreased the most in the north (i.e., Lake Superior, Northern Lake Michigan and Huron) and in coastal areas
- Ice cover on the Great Lakes will likely continue to decrease in the future, however, these decreases are expected to be interrupted by high-ice winters associated with cold air outbreaks.
- Reduced ice cover results in more winter lake-effect precipitation and increased winter wave activity.
4

**A more in-depth analysis of Great Lakes ice cover is available here from GLISA in our Sustained Assessment of the Lakes resource.**

**Historical Trends**

Ice formation is influenced by the physical properties of the lakes (e.g., lake depth) and complex temperature-driven dynamics, which allows for large variability in ice conditions day-to-day, week-to-week, and year-to-year. Weekly variations in ice cover can be larger than the seasonal mean indicating large “swings” in ice conditions can occur on short time scales.[ 5](https://glisa.umich.edu#easy-footnote-bottom-5-918) These swings may be due to extreme weather events controlled by internal climate patterns such as Arctic Oscillation (AO) and ENSO.

[On annual time scales, a winter with high ice cover can contribute to low ice cover the next year, and vice versa – a result of the complex relationship between ice cover, lake temperatures, and lake evaporation. This behavior speaks to the longer term “memory,” or heat capacity, of the lakes and how the effects of current conditions can carry over days, seasons, and years ahead.](https://glisa.umich.edu#easy-footnote-bottom-6-918)

6The lakes have experienced less ice cover on average during the last 20-30 years compared to earlier years, prior to th…

[Truncated preview: showing 374 words out of ~1869. Full content available via `btf_extract_evidence`.]

- Reduced ice cover results in more winter lake-effect precipitation and increased winter wave activity.
4

**A more in-depth analysis of Great Lakes ice cover is available here from GLISA in our Sustained Assessment of the Lakes resource.**

**Historical Trends**

Ice formation is influenced by the physical properties of the lakes (e.g., lake depth) and complex temperature-driven dynamics, which allows for large variability in ice conditions day-to-day, week-to-week, and year-to-year. Weekly variations in ice cover can be larger than the seasonal mean indicating large “swings” in ice conditions can occur on short time scales.[ 5](https://glisa.umich.edu#easy-footnote-bottom-5-918) These swings may be due to extreme weather events controlled by internal climate patterns such as Arctic Oscillation (AO) and ENSO.

[On annual time scales, a winter with high ice cover can contribute to low ice cover the next year, and vice versa – a result of the complex relationship between ice cover, lake temperatures, and lake evaporation. This behavior speaks to the longer term “memory,” or heat capacity, of the lakes and how the effects of current conditions can carry over days, seasons, and years ahead.](https://glisa.umich.edu#easy-footnote-bottom-6-918)

6The lakes have experienced less ice cover on average during the last 20-30 years compared to earlier years, prior to th…

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will the Great Lakes ice coverage be between 15.0% and 30.0% (inclusive) on March 30, 2025?
Background: Please see the resources by the Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory [here](https://www.glerl.noaa.gov/data/ice/#currentConditions).
Resolution criteria: This question resolves as YES if the 'GL Total' figure for Great Lakes average ice concentration according to [this data set](https://apps.glerl.noaa.gov/coastwatch/webdata/statistic/ice/dat/g2024_2025_ice.dat) for the 89th day of 2025 is greater than or equal to 15.0% and less than or equal to 30.0%. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.
Fine print: If the resolution source fails to update before the end of this tournament, then the most recent day preceding day 89 will be used to resolve the question.
present_date: 2025-03-23T08:38:42.125823


Make sure to use the tools at your disposal to gather relevant information before providing your final probability estimate.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

{"url": "https://medium.com/michigan-news/daily-great-lakes-ice-cover-report-march-15-2025-c658096ce57d", "snippet": "---
title: Daily Great Lakes Ice Cover Report — March 15, 2025
author: Thumbwind Publications
url: https://medium.com/michigan-news/daily-great-lakes-ice-cover-report-march-15-2025-c658096ce57d
hostname: medium.com
sitename: Michigan News
date: 2025-03-15
---
# Daily Great Lakes Ice Cover Report — March 15, 2025

Winter is now waning across the upper Great Lakes region. As ice cover is reduced, changes in weather patterns and lake activities will be seen. This daily Great Lakes ice cover report provides the latest updates on ice conditions across the lakes.

**Lake Superior:** 11.54%

**Lake Michigan:** 11.83%

**Lake Huron:** 21.79%

**Lake Erie:** 28.00%

**Lake Ontario:** 11.94%

**Lake St. Clair:** 14.50%

**Great Lakes Consolidated Ice Coverage:** 15.63%

Data from GLERL.NOAA.GOV. Stay tuned for daily updates on Great Lakes ice cover as we monitor changing conditions throughout the season.", "word_count": 124, "snippet_word_count": 124, "snippet_truncated": false, "date_cutoff_start": "2025-02-23T08:38:42.125823", "date_cutoff_end": "2025-03-24T08:38:42.125823", "cached_at": "2025-10-24T03:20:37.702248"}

messages.content:
{"url": "https://glisa.umich.edu/resources-tools/climate-impacts/great-lakes-ice-coverage/", "snippet": "---
title: Great Lakes Ice Coverage
url: https://glisa.umich.edu/resources-tools/climate-impacts/great-lakes-ice-coverage/
hostname: umich.edu
sitename: glisa.umich.edu
date: 2017-08-01
---
# Great Lakes Ice Coverage

**NOTE: This page is no longer updated as of 2021, and more recently updated information is now available through GLISA’s Sustained Assessment of the Great Lakes and Great Lakes Retrospectives and Prospectives pages.**

**Summary**

- The number of days per winter with lake ice coverage has declined since the start of record in 1973.
1 - In most areas, ice cover declines were a sudden shift as opposed to a gradual decline. For Lakes Michigan, Erie, and Ontario the shift occurred in the mid-1980s, but for Lakes Superior and Huron the shift occurred during the 1997/98 winter.
23 - Ice cover has decreased the most in the north (i.e., Lake Superior, Northern Lake Michigan and Huron) and in coastal areas
- Ice cover on the Great Lakes will likely continue to decrease in the future, however, these decreases are expected to be interrupted by high-ice winters associated with cold air outbreaks.
- Reduced ice cover results in more winter lake-effect precipitation and increased winter wave activity.
4

**A more in-depth analysis of Great Lakes ice cover is available here from GLISA in our Sustained Assessment of the Lakes resource.**

**Historical Trends**

Ice formation is influenced by the physical properties of the lakes (e.g., lake depth) and complex temperature-driven dynamics, which allows for large variability in ice conditions day-to-day, week-to-week, and year-to-year. Weekly variations in ice cover can be larger than the seasonal mean indicating large “swings” in ice conditions can occur on short time scales.[ 5](https://glisa.umich.edu#easy-footnote-bottom-5-918) These swings may be due to extreme weather events controlled by internal climate patterns such as Arctic Oscillation (AO) and ENSO.

[On annual time scales, a winter with high ice cover can contribute to low ice cover the next year, and vice versa – a result of the complex relationship between ice cover, lake temperatures, and lake evaporation. This behavior speaks to the longer term “memory,” or heat capacity, of the lakes and how the effects of current conditions can carry over days, seasons, and years ahead.](https://glisa.umich.edu#easy-footnote-bottom-6-918)

6The lakes have experienced less ice cover on average during the last 20-30 years compared to earlier years, prior to th…

[Truncated preview: showing 374 words out of ~1869. Full content available via `btf_extract_evidence`.]", "word_count": 1869, "snippet_word_count": 374, "snippet_truncated": true, "date_cutoff_start": "2025-02-23T08:38:42.125823", "date_cutoff_end": "2025-03-24T08:38:42.125823", "cached_at": "2025-10-24T03:20:38.187332"}

messages.content:
Based on the information gathered, here are some key facts:

1. As of March 15, 2025, the Great Lakes Consolidated Ice Coverage is 15.63%. This is within the target range of 15.0% to 30.0% for the resolution of the question.
2. Individual ice coverage for the lakes as of March 15, 2025, are:
   - Lake Superior: 11.54%
   - Lake Michigan: 11.83%
   - Lake Huron: 21.79%
   - Lake Erie: 28.00%
   - Lake Ontario: 11.94%

The current ice coverage is just above the lower threshold of 15.0%. Given that the present date is March 23, 2025, and the ice coverage is already within the desired range, it is likely that the ice coverage will remain within this range until March 30, 2025, unless there are significant weather changes.

Considering historical trends and current conditions, the probability that the Great Lakes ice coverage will be between 15.0% and 30.0% on March 30, 2025, is relatively high.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.75
